text.text:
These London bakeries are staffed by properly skilled artisans; peoples dedicated to honing the fine art of pastry, meticulously folding layer upon layer with oh so much butter.

Sure there's a Sainsbury's on every corner that can provide a thoroughly unromantic cheese twist at a moment's notice, but don't you deserve better? You're a stand-up sort, you recycle, you've held open a few doors recently. Cripes if you're not allowed the pastry life then who is?

tip.text:
Originally a stall on Broadway Market, Violet (Claire Ptak) has upgraded to this postcard-perfect brick and mortar outpost whilst also pumping out cookbooks left, right and centre. This golden bakery is a lovely spot to while away an hour or two, especially in the lovely outdoor area out back in the summer months.

Cupcakes are gorgeous, cinnamon buns a lip-smacking delight, there isn't a cake this lady can't do - she even made a lemon and elderflower number for Megan and Harry's big day. Yep you're eating the good stuff here.

text.text: Originally a stall on Broadway Market, Violet (Claire Ptak) has upgraded to this postcard-perfect brick-and-mortar outpost whilst also pumping out cookbooks left, right and centre. Her cupcakes are gorgeous; her cinnamon buns a lip-smacking delight - there isn't a cake this lady can't do, she even made a lemon and elderflower number for Megan and Harry's big day.

tip.text:
Ollie had been dreaming of opening a bakery for years and, ocassionally, dreams do come true. Settling near the canal in Islington, Pophams' looks to do things differently. All pastries here are handmade in the morning (which means head baker Florin has to get up at around 2am to laminate his croissants), and flavours are boundless. Sure they've a faultless plain croissant on offer, but they also make a mean almond croissant, a ham and cheese version or a rosemary and salt plat.

And, friends, it doesn't stop there. This is a place where a maple and bacon croissant is possible; or one with... wait for it... peanut butter, raspberry jam and banana slices. If all the choices wear you out, a sit down in the muted tones, and plant filled surroundings should ease your nerves. Bon apptit!

text.text: Ollie had been dreaming of opening a bakery for years until he finally settled near the canal in Islington. All pastries here are handmade in the morning (which means head baker Florin has to get up at around 2am to laminate his croissants). His plain croissant is faultless but it doesn't stop there. This is a place where a maple and bacon croissant is possible; or one with... wait for it... peanut butter, raspberry jam and banana slices.

tip.text:
There may only be a brief window on Saturday when you can get your hands on the Little Bread Pedlars stuff, but trust us, its worth it. Roll out of bed and down to Spa Terminus for some seriously devour-worthy pastries, ridiculously light and airy and fresh out of the oven.

These folks started out peddling their bread at market stalls, and now whizz round London on deli bikes supplying restaurants and cafs with their artisan wares. Get in between 8.30am and 2pm for sourdough loaves, croissants, quiches, and signature pastries like the Parma Rose parma ham wrapped in a nest of croissant dough.

text.text: There may only be a brief window on Saturday when you can get your hands on the Little Bread Pedlars stuff, but trust us, its worth it. Roll out of bed and down to Spa Terminus for some seriously devour-worthy pastries, ridiculously light and airy and fresh out of the oven. Get in between 8.30am and 2pm for sourdough loaves, croissants, quiches, and signature pastries like the Parma Rose - parma ham wrapped in a nest of croissant dough.

tip.text:
If we were the suspicious sorts, we'd begin to suspect there was something a little fishy about E5 and their growing bakery empire. How did they expand so quick? Is that flour really flour? Are they planning on a bread monopoly? But let's put those concerns to one side and enjoy this institution for what it is: a purveyor of delicious organic and natural sourdough bread.

In one arch you'll find the cafe, a busy hub where affluent Hackneyites come in for their routine cup of joe, fresh lunches and cakes and treats. In another arch, you've got their store, which is all about artisan goods at appropriately inflated prices. And then the mill itself, where all that...milling takes place and the dough transforms into truly delicious bread. Look out for their bread and pizza making classes too, which are super popular.

text.text: In an arch of E5 you'll find this cafe - a busy hub where affluent Hackneyites come in for their routine cup of joe, fresh lunches and cakes and treats. In another arch, you've got their store, which is all about artisan goods at appropriately inflated prices. And then the mill itself. They're nailing croissants, cinnamon rolls and their little known savoury sibling the cheddar and marmite roll. It's pastry magic.

tip.text:
This Japanese bakery and caf is all clean lines, neat and tidy, with a perfectly presented selection of patisseries. Pop in for a coffee and have a peruse of the eye opening selection of bakes. Choosing really is tricky with all sorts of tarts, buns and cakes on offer. Try a simple matcha roll or go big with a 'choux trios', which looks like three joined up profiteroles filled with whipped sesame, matcha and azuki custard.

If you're after something savoury there's a banging selection of breads and sarnies too - chicken katsu sandos, pumpkin rolls, curry buns or the amazing egg mayo bun - it's curry-flavoured dough filled with egg mayo, coated in breadcrumbs and cornflakes and deep fried - wowza.

text.text: This Japanese bakery and caf is all clean modern lines, proper neat and tidy, with a perfectly presented selection of patisseries. Choosing between all these parcels of wonder really is tricky, there's all sorts of tarts, buns and cakes on offer. Try a simple matcha roll or go big with a 'choux trios', which looks like three joined up profiteroles filled with whipped sesame, matcha and azuki custard.

tip.text:
Another bakery in a railway arch. Well if it ain't broke... And Yeast Bakery sure isn't with their sugary Saturday fodder to take away. Seeing as they specialise in 'viennoiserie', there's plenty of French goodies on offer - including classics like croissants, pain au chocolats, pain au raisin and more intriguing inventions like the brioches feuilletes.

Ideally you'll be able to share a few with your fellow fiends but if you're only buying one make it the kouign-amann. It's an obscure Breton bake made with layer upon layer of pastry, butter and sugar. It's a pretty laborious process but you end up with something resembling a caramelised croissant. It really is summin else.

text.text: Another bakery in a railway arch... well if it ain't broke. Yeast Bakery specialise in 'viennoiserie' which means all sorts of pains au chocolat, pains au raisin, brioches feuilletes and the elusive kouign-amann: an obscure Breton bake made with layer upon layer of pastry, butter and sugar. It's a pretty laborious process but you end up with something resembling a caramelised croissant. It really is summin' else.
